Class Dictionary

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.Observable
      • simplex.Dictionary

  • public class Dictionary
extends java.util.Observable
    Class that models a dictionary

      • Dictionary

        public Dictionary(int nbBasicVar,
          int nbNonBasicVar,
          EnteringMethod method,
          boolean bland)
        Constructs a dictionary corresponding to the parameters. Knowing the number of rows and columns, the allocation of the arrays needed for coding is done by this constructor.
        Parameters:
        nbBasicVar - number of constraints
        nbHorsbase - number of decision variables (main variables)
        method - specifes the method to adopt for the choice of the entering variable
        bland - specifes if one uses the rule of Bland

    • Method Detail

      • isFeasible

        public boolean isFeasible()
        TO IMPLEMENT FIRST; determines if the dictionary is feasible It is necessary for that to examine D[i][0] for the index i which varies from 1 to nbBasisVar and use the definition of a feasible dictionary.
        Returns:
        returns true if the dictionary is feasible, returns false otherwise

      • searchFirstIndexEnteringVariable

        public int searchFirstIndexEnteringVariable()
        TO IMPLEMENT; we look for the index in arrayNonBasicVar of the "first" candidate to enter in basis by considering the variables in the order they occupy in arrayNonBasicVar. For example, suppose that D[0][1] <= 0 and that D[0][2]> 0. The method then returns the value 2. If arrayNonBasicVar[2] for example contains the value 3, it means that the variable x3 is chosen as entering variable but this does not intervene in the programming. For this search, we go through D[0][j] for j which varies from 1 to nbNonBasicVar and we keep the index corresponding to the first strictly positive coefficient encountered if there is such an index. The numbers of the variables do not matter.
        Returns:
        If there is an entering variable, returns the smallest index of an entering variable, that is, the smallest positive index of a box of the array D[0][...] containing a strictly positive value. otherwise, returns 0.

      • searchIndexLeavingVariable

        public int searchIndexLeavingVariable(int jE)
        TO IMPLEMENT; an entering variable being chosen, look for a leaving variable. Variable numbers do not matter.
        Parameters:
        jE - the index in arrayNonBasicVar of the entering variable, i.e. the index of the column of D that will be used in this method. In this method, we must use D[i][0] and D[i][jE] for the index i which varies from 1 to nbBasicVar.
        Returns:
        If the dictionary shows that the problem is not bounded, returns 0. Otherwise, returns the index in arrayBasicVar of a leaving variable, i.e. the index of the row of the matrix D corresponding to the leaving variable.

      • pivote

        public void pivote(int iS,
          int jE)
        TO IMPLEMENT; modifies the current dictionary (referenced by this) by pivoting according to the indicated parameters .
        Parameters:
        iS - the index in arrayBasicVar of the leaving variable (i.e. index in D of the line from from which we pivot)

      • searchIndexEnteringVariableGreatestCoeff

        public int searchIndexEnteringVariableGreatestCoeff()
        TO IMPLEMENT; look for an entering variable of greatest coefficient in the objective function of the current dictionary. The numbers of the variables do not matter. Only D[0][j] for j which varies from 1 to nbNonBasisVar is concerned.
        Returns:
        If there is an entering variable, returns the index in arrayNonBasicVar of the entering variable of greatest coefficient in the objective of the current dictionary, i.e. the index >= 1 in D [0][...] of the greatest value box.
        otherwise, returns 0c

      • searchEnteringAdvantageousVariableIndex

        public int searchEnteringAdvantageousVariableIndex()
        To implement; looks for an entering variable that maximizes the increase of the objective function in the next dictionary. The numbers of the variables do not matter.
        Returns:
        If there is no entering variable, returns 0;
        otherwise if there is an entering variable that gives an infinite increase (problem not bounded), returns the value -1;
        otherwise returns the index in arrayNonBasicVar of the entering variable that maximizes the increase of the objective function in the next dictionary.

      • searchIndexEnteringVariableSmallestNumber

        public int searchIndexEnteringVariableSmallestNumber()
        TO IMPLEMENT: look for the index of the entering variable of smallest number (the variable x_i has number i). Serves when using Bland's rule. For example, if arrayNonBasicVar contains from index 1 the numbers 6, 7, 2, 3, 5 and if the variables candidate to enter are the variables of indices 2 and 4 (arrayNonBasicVar[2] is 7, arrayNonBasicVar[4] is 3), the returned value is 4.
        Returns:
        If there is an entering variable, returns the index in arrayNonBasicVar of the entering variable of smallest number.
        Otherwise, returns 0.

      • searchIndexLeavingVariableSmallestNumber

        public int searchIndexLeavingVariableSmallestNumber(int jE)
        TO IMPLEMENT; an entering variable being chosen, look for the index of the leaving variable of smallest number (the variable x_i has number i). Serves when using Bland's rule. For example, if arrayBasicVar contains from index 1 the numbers 4, 5, 1, 2, 7 and if the variables candidate to leave are the variables of indices 2 and 4 (arrayBasicVar[2] is 5, arrayBasicVar[4] is 2), the returned value is 4.
        Returns:
        If the dictionary shows that the problem is not bounded, returns -1.
        else, returns the index of the leaving variable.

      • searchIndexEnteringVariable

        public int searchIndexEnteringVariable(EnteringMethod methode)

      • oneStep

        public void oneStep()
        Performs a step in the simplex method. If the dictionary is optimal, set the attribute "optimal" to true
        If step has shown that the problem is not bounded, set the terminal attribute to false In the other cases, performs a step of the simplex method by choosing an entering variable, an leaving variable and pivoting.

      • oneStep

        public void oneStep(int jE)

      • oneStep

        public void oneStep(int jE,
           int iS)

      • firstAuxiliaryDictionaryPhase1

        public Dictionary firstAuxiliaryDictionaryPhase1()
        Caomputes a first dictionary, not feasible, for the first phase.
        The introduced variable is named x0 (in other words it has the number 0) and it is assumed that no other variable has the number 0.
        Returns:
        returns a first dictionary, not feasible, for the first phase.

      • firstFeasibleDictionaryPhase1

        public void firstFeasibleDictionaryPhase1()
        The current dictionary is the first dictionary, not feasible, of the first phase (the dictionary obtained by the method firstDicoPbAuxiliary); modifies this dictionary to have a first feasible dictionary for the first phase.

      • initialDictionaryPhase2

        public Dictionary initialDictionaryPhase2(double[] zInitial,
                                 double z0Initial,
                                 int[] initialNonBasicVar)
        From a dictionary of the first phase (dictionary of the auxiliary problem) such as the value of the objective function in the associated basic solution is 0 (which shows that the initial problem is feasible), computes the first dictionary of the second phase. Do not change the dictionary. For it :
        - we remove the variable x0 (the number columns decreases by 1);
        - we compute the objective function according to the non-basis variables
        Parameters:
        zInitial - the linear part of the objective function expressed according to the decision variables
        z0Initial - the constant of the objective function expressed according to the decision variables
        Returns:
        returns the resulting dictionary giving the initial dictionary of the second phase

      • basicIndex

        public int basicIndex(int var)
        Check if the variable indicated in parameter is in base.
        Parameters:
        var - the number of the searched variable.
        Returns:
        if the variable indicated in parameter is in base, returns the index of this variable in arrayBasicVar (between 1 and nbLines); otherwise, returns 0.

      • nonBasicIndex

        public int nonBasicIndex(int var)
        Check if the variable specified in parameter is non-basic.
        Parameters:
        var - the number of the searched variable
        Returns:
        if the variable specified in parameter is non-basic, returns the index of this variable (between 1 and nbColums); otherwise, returns 0

      • enteringLeaving

        public java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer>[] enteringLeaving(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> listBasic)
        Parameters:
        listBasic - list of variable numbers you want in base
        Returns:
        the two lists in an array of two ArrayList of indices of entering variables and indices of leaving variables

                            int numE)
        pivotes by considering the numbers of the entering and leaving variables
        Parameters:
        numE - the number of the entering variable
        numS - the number of the leaving variable
